title: The Great Stink of London
description: A quick, practical guide to The Great Stink of London.

hook.text: In 1858, the Thames reeked so badly Parliament fled. Curtains soaked in lime chloride couldn't mask the stench.

buildup.text: London had 200,000 cesspits draining into the Thamesâ€”its drinking water source. Cholera killed tens of thousands.

discovery.text: Joseph Bazalgette proposed a radical fix: 1,300 miles of underground sewers intercepting waste before the Thames.

twist.text: Parliament refused funds for yearsâ€”until the stench hit their own chambers. Self-interest, not health, built sewers.

climax.text: Bazalgette oversized his sewers for future growth. They still serve Londonâ€”built for triple his era's population.

punchline.text: It took a bad smell in Parliament to save millions.

quiz.question: What finally motivated Parliament to fund London's sewer system?
options: The Thames stench became unbearable inside Parliament itself
A cholera epidemic killed several members of Parliament
Queen Victoria personally ordered the construction
